Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Application of high precision isotope tracer measurements to resolve rates of aquatic denitrification
Award.AbstractNarration:
Denitrification is the natural process by which nitrate is reduced to harmless N2 gas. Denitrification reduces loading of nitrate to the biosphere, thereby minimizing coastal eutrophication and hypoxia and emissions of the greenhouse gas, nitrous oxide. Watersheds represent the greatest sink for natural and anthropogenic nitrate; however, rates of denitrification, particularly at ecosystem scales, are poorly understood. Denitrification in streams can be evaluated at ecosystem scales by addition of nitrate enriched in the stable nitrogen isotope 15N and measurement of the accumulation of 15N in N2. This study will develop novel analytical methodology for vastly improving the accuracy and precision of the N2 stable isotope ratio, which will enable application of 15N-nitrate tracer studies in environments where it is currently impractical to do so. EAGER funding is appropriate as this method development is exploratory; nonetheless the project has great potential to transform the approach for and knowledge of the denitrification process.

Excessive nitrate loading and its role in eutrophication is one of the most significant impacts of a large and growing human population. Thus, the broader significance and potential impacts of this research are that the methodology proposed will provide ecosystem managers information to understand natural rates of nitrate removal as well as a foundation to manage natural and man-made environments to foster denitrification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Denitrification is a natural microbial process that helps mitigate nitrogen pollution of terrestrial and aquatic environments, thereby reducing coastal eutrophication and hypoxia.  In this process nitrate is reduced to harmless N2 gas, although a small proportion also becomes nitrous oxide, which is a particularly potent heat-trapping gas in the atmosphere. For both of these reasons scientists are keenly interested in learning when and where denitrification takes place in watersheds as nitrate is carried by water flowing from land to lakes and oceans.

 The rates and controls of denitrification, particularly at ecosystem scales, are poorly understood, in large part due to methodological limitations.  Measurements in microcosms (small containers) may alter rates in unknown ways. Denitrification in entire stream reaches can be evaluated by stable isotope tracer studies entailing the addition of 15N enriched nitrate and measurement of the accumulation of 15N in N2.  However such experiments require large amounts of expensive 15N tracer, and in many environments they lack the sensitivity we need to measure denitrification. In this study we developed novel analytical methodology for vastly improving the accuracy and precision of the measurement of the N2 stable isotope ratio, an important step towards the application of 15N-nitrate tracer studies in environments that have posed challenges for traditional methods. We subsequently applied this new method in a series of laboratory (flume) and natural stream environments. We found good agreement between our novel high-precision measurements and a traditional method.

 Broader Impacts: Excessive nitrate loading to watersheds and its role in eutrophication of downstream waters is one of the most significant impacts of a large human population.  The methodology developed in this study has the potential to be more broadly employed and thereby provide ecosystem managers information to better understand natural rates of nitrate removal. Such research will help build a stronger scientific foundation to manage natural and man-made environments to foster denitrification. 

 The project involved two graduate students and was conducted at the Kellogg Biological Station’s Long Term Ecological Research (KBS LTER) site and at another LTER site in Kansas (Konza Biological Station). At KBS Co-PI Hamilton regularly participated in a variety of educational and outreach activities, many linked to the KBS LTER, to involve undergraduate students, K-12 school groups, unrepresented groups, and the public in the activities and findings of our research. He also leads a local watershed council that deals with non-point-source pollution of streams and rivers.
